ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

EMPLOYMENT OF GRADUATES OF
INDUSTRIAL TRAINING BOARD


    1. Encik Sidek bin Saniff asked the Prime Minister how long after completing their courses does it take graduates of institutes of the Industrial Training Board to obtain employment.

     The Acting Minister for Social Affairs (Dr Ahmad Mattar) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, surveys of ITB graduates are conducted six months after they complete training to determine their employment status. It was found that of the 1975-76 graduates, 43% were in full-time national service and 15% were pursuing further studies/training, while 28% were employed and 14% were looking for a job, staying at home or did not state their employment status. The great majority, 77%, of working graduates found jobs within three months; 91% within six months. Industrial Technician Certificate (ITC) graduates generally fared better than the average.

    Surveys are also conducted of ITB graduates demobbed from national service to determine their employment status. Of those demobbed in 1975 and 1976, 69% were in employment while 5% were pursuing higher studies or staying at home. The remainder 26% were looking for a job. Of those employed, 78% had found employment within three months. Of those looking for a job, only 23% had been job-hunting for more than six months.

ACUPUNCTURE PRACTICE IN
SINGAPORE


    2. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Health (a) whether and what proficiency requirements are laid down by his Ministry for the practice of acupuncture in Singapore; and (b) whether his Ministry is aware of an article in the newspaper West Australian of 23rd September, 1977, alleging ease with which certificates of proficiency in acupuncture can be obtained in

Column: 1134

Singapore, and if it has looked, or intends to look, into the matter.

     The Minister for Health (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no legislation in Singapore controlling the practice of acupuncture. My Ministry does not issue certificates of proficiency in acupuncture nor is it our intention in the future to control acupuncture which is empirical and is part of traditional Chinese medical practice.

    The answer to part (b) is that my Ministry does not subscribe to the West Australian, nor does the Parliament library. I do not see a copy of this paper in the Members' Room. So the answer is: I do not know what the West Australian is alleging.

WEIGHTS AND MEASURES
(Prosecutions)


    4. Mr Ivan Baptist asked the Minister for Law, the Environment and Science and Technology (a) how many times every month during the last six months have the Weights and Measures office verified weighing and measuring instruments in markets, shops and other retail outlets; and (b) how many persons were prosecuted with regard to possession and use of faulty weights and short measure every month for the last six months in markets, shops and other retail outlets.

     The Minister for Law, the Environment and Science and Technology (Mr E.W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, officers of the Weights and Measures office carry out regular checks on weighing and measuring instruments in markets, shops and other retail outlets. If the instruments are found to be incorrect or tampered with, they are brought back to the office for further inspection. Summonses are issued to the users if it is confirmed that their instruments are faulty.

Column: 1136



    Over the last six months, the office made spot checks on 60 days, or approximately 10 days per month. In all, about 9,300 weighing and measuring instruments were checked in various places. During the same period, that is to say, the last six months, between four and 11 offenders were prosecuted every month. Of the total of 38 persons prosecuted, 35 were convicted for possession and use of faulty instruments. The fines imposed ranged from $100 to $500. Under the Act, any person committing an offence is liable on conviction to a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding three months or both. I mentioned that 38 persons were prosecuted. Of this number, three cases are still pending a hearing in court.

     Mr Ivan Baptist: Sir, is the Weights and Measures office frequently triggered off by complaints from consumers? If so, how many inspections and prosecutions resulted from consumers' complaints?

     Mr Barker: Sir, the office carries out regular checks. On receiving complaints, they make further checks. But I am afraid I cannot answer the last supplementary question as to how many prosecutions resulted from complaints as I do not have the figures here.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Sir, having faulty instruments is one thing but having correct instruments but dishonest reading -

     Mr Speaker: Dr Tan, are you asking a supplementary question?

     Dr Augustine Tan: Yes. I am leading to a question, Sir.

     Mr Speaker: Are you?

     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, the instruments may be correct but the people who read them are dishonest. Has the Minister got any such cases?

     Mr Barker: Sir, not as far as I am aware of. But the Member has a point. The instrument may be correct but it is up to the consumer to check the instrument whenever he buys. The officer goes out to check whether the instruments are faulty. If there is

Column: 1137

blatant cheating going on, it is difficult to check unless the officer is there himself.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, a supplementary question. Since the daching particularly can be used for cheating purposes, is the Ministry considering banning the daching?

     Mr Barker: Sir, we are not banning the daching because it has been used for more than 100 years in Singapore. There have been frequent cheatings on the daching, but the consumer too is becoming a little cleverer these days and most of them can read the daching.

     Mr Ivan Baptist: Sir, on average how long would it take for the Weights and Measures office to respond to a consumer's complaint?

     Mr Barker: I would say in a matter of two to three days.

     Mr Ivan Baptist: Sir, would that not be too long because the retailer concerned could by then have removed the faulty weighing or measuring instrument or those bags of rice or sugar? So it will be impossible for the Weights and Measures office to check.

     Mr Barker: Sir, it really depends. When I say "within two to three days", I do not mean that we go on the third day.

    Question again proposed

     The Minister for Home Affairs and Education (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Sir, before the House rose on Friday, 17th March, I was still replying to the Member for Anson.

    I remember I stopped at the point of his complaint that the traffic enforcement officers did not extend courtesy and consideration when enforcing the law. I believe, Sir, the Member for Anson has a tendency to exaggerate. The enforcement officers of the Traffic Police have been constantly reminded to extend care, courtesy and consideration in enforcing the law. Any complaint against enforcers for lack of discretion, courtesy and common sense in the application of the law is duly investigated into and those found guilty are taken to task. Very often, Sir, these complaints are groundless as shown by some facts and figures which I would like to state here. During last year, a total of 25 complaints were made against Traffic Police personnel. Of these, only five complaints were sustained and action was taken against these five persons.

    The Member for Anson also did state that any person could impersonate a Police Officer and issue traffic summonses. Sir, this really tops the example of his propensity to exaggerate. May I assure him that nobody, except the Police and other authorised

Column: 1139

personnel, can issue summonses. However, anyone can make a report either by writing to the Traffic Police or personally going to a Police station. Action against the driver will only be taken after the report has been fully investigated and found to be correct.
2.45 p.m.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the next point concerns the issue of summons to the wrong person. The strict procedure that we have makes it rather remote for summonses to be issued to the wrong persons. When a traffic offence is committed, the police officers spotting it will take down the particulars of the vehicle, such as the make of the vehicle, its colour and registration number. These particulars are then checked with the records at the Registry of Vehicles before a summons is issued to the registered owner. Invariably the notice is served on the owner for particulars of the driver if the owner himself was not driving the car. There is always the possibility that the owner was not driving his vehicle at the time of the offence but somebody else was. The onus is on the owner to show that he did not commit the offence. In the case cited by the Member, the absence of the owner from Singapore does not necessarily mean that his vehicle was not used by someone else. I think the police should be commended for obviously giving this owner the benefit of the doubt when it decided not to pursue the matter.

    The Member has also alleged that the traffic enforcement officers have failed to use their discretion to lot off offenders who have not used the pedestrian crossings unintentionally. The Pedestrian Crossing Rules came into force on 1st July, 1977 after one month of intensive campaigning. But penalties were not imposed until 1st September, 1977, that is, after a further three months of intensive campaigning. Between 1st July and 1st September we had a massive campaign to educate the pedestrians. Therefore, there is no reason for the people to continue to flout the Pedestrian Crossing Rules. It is only by vigorous

Column: 1140

enforcement of recalcitrant offenders that jaywalking can be reduced.

    To indicate how effective the Pedestrian Crossing Rules have been for the three months from July to September, I would like to quote some figures. Between September and December 1977, there were 784 pedestrian-related accidents compared to 979 for the corresponding period in 1976. In other words, there was a decrease of 19.9% of pedestrian-related accidents after the campaign.

    Lastly, the Member for Anson has again brought up the question of Wallich Street. He said that there had been some improvement in the situation now. I shall therefore leave it at that.

    May I now reply to the points raised by the Member for Telok Blangah. Members will recall that the Member for Telok Blangah stated in his speech that he noticed that the number of staff in the Traffic Enforcement Section for FY 78 had remained the same as that compared with FY 77. But at the same time he said that there is a current shortage of staff. He wanted clarification as to why the Enforcement staff has not increased. May I say that one simple way of discouraging and apprehending traffic offenders is to deploy a large number of policemen on the streets. But this will entail the expansion of the Traffic Police Department. There is a limit to the number of Enforcement staff we can expand. My Ministry has considered this problem very carefully and has decided that we should work out a strategy for a more efficient and intelligent deployment of our manpower by first using our existing strength of police officers. To this end we have taken the following measures:

    First, Traffic Enforcement Squads are being formed in the eight Police Divisions with existing officers. The operational efficiency of the Divisions will not be adversely affected since some of the more routine duties in the Divisions can be given to full-time national servicemen.

    Secondly, the Traffic Police has also adopted a new strategy to deal with traffic

Column: 1141

offenders with effect from 10th July last year. Ten unmarked police cars have been used to track down traffic offenders. More cars will be acquired. With effect from 24th October last year some officers in the Mobile. Squad have also been deployed as plainclothes men to track down traffic offenders. There are presently 10 such officers in each shift.

    Thirdly, the Traffic Police has been directed to be more selective in enforcement instead of being indiscriminate about it. They have been directed to concentrate on the more serious traffic offences such- as dangerous driving, inconsiderate and careless driving and give less priority to minor offences like parking offences. All senior police officers have also been instructed to report the commission of such traffic offences while they are travelling on the road, on duty or otherwise. The number of such offenders booked on the road in the last three months is as follows. This is the combined total of offenders booked by both the Mobile Squad as well as the senior police officers. Eighty-one offenders were booked for dangerous driving, 140 offenders for careless driving; and 1,421 for inconsiderate driving, making a total of 1,642 cases of dangerous driving, careless driving and inconsiderate driving booked for the last three months from December 1977 to February 1978. However, if it is found necessary to expand the Traffic Enforcement Squad by recruiting new officers, this will be done. But what I would like to emphasise is that we must adopt a new strategy to deploy our resources more intelligently to obtain better results.

    Fourthly, for the information of the Member for Telok Blangah, there is now no bottleneck in the issue of summonses.

    Let me now come back to the Member for Kim Seng. I remember that he wanted clarification on certain points, including the Highway Code. He stated that he had forgotten most of the Highway Code because it has been a long time since he took his driving test.

     An hon. Member: Withdraw his licence!

Column: 1142



     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, I do not act arbitrarily by withdrawing people's licences. First, may I clarify the position regarding fast and slow lanes. According to the existing rules in the Highway Code, every vehicle moving at a slow speed shall be driven as close to the left hand edge of the roadway as possible, and every vehicle shall at all times be driven in such a manner as not to obstruct vehicles moving at a faster speed. Given this rule, it is quite clear that the left-most lane is the proper lane for slow- moving vehicles. The right and centre lanes are therefore fast moving lanes. However, vehicles wishing to make a right turn are permitted to travel on the right lane if they are slowing down to do the turn. I hope that explanation is quite clear.

    As regards his question on the number of persons booked for road hogging, my answer is that 5,081 persons have been so booked in 1977.

    The next point is the green arrow for a right turn. The Public Works Department is at the moment carrying out a pilot scheme to study the feasibility of using a flashing filter arrow, a point which was brought up by a Member, to forewarn turning vehicles of an impending change in the light signal. For example, at the junction of Tanjong Katong Road and East Coast Road, the filter arrow flashes for a duration of six seconds before it goes off, So there should be sufficient warning. If the pilot scheme proves to be effective, the Public Works Department will install flashing filter arrows at appropriate junctions, including the one mentioned by the Member for Kim Seng.

    On the question of more red-man and green-man signals at junctions, I cannot agree with the Member for Kim Seng more that more of such traffic signals should be installed at junctions. In fact, this is being done by the PWD. The PWD is also planning to install green-man and red-man signals at all new junctions. The Road engineers from the PWD have also, with the advice of the Traffic Police, been adjusting the timing of the green-man signal, to provide a safe minimum time for pedestrians to cross so

Column: 1143

that turning vehicles will not be unduly delayed and cause traffic congestion.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to recall a matter which I raised previously under the Ministry of Health, in regard to traffic regulations pertaining to drivers of motor vehicles who fail to give way to ambulances and fire engines. Would the Minister ensure that better enforcement in this regard is effected? Furthermore, he would perhaps like to consider giving authority to the staff of ambulances and fire engines to issue summonses against drivers who fail to give way.
3.00 p.m.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I cannot agree with the Member for Whampoa more by saying that those who refuse to give way to ambulances should be booked and punished. But I cannot agree with him that authority for issuing summonses should be given to ambulance drivers. The Member for Anson has brought up the point that summonses could be issued by any Tom, Dick and Harry. In fact, we have a very strict procedure and only authorised persons are allowed to issue a summons. I do not think ambulance drivers are appropriate persons to be authorised to issue summonses. In fact, summonses have to be signed by a magistrate before they are issued.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, what about educational programmes on TV and radio and in the schools to teach people that they must give way to ambulances and fire engines in the interest perhaps of their beloved ones in times of crisis and in terms of citizens in general?

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, there are many matters which we would like to educate the public, not only just giving way to ambulances and fire engines. In fact, this is being done through our campaigns followed by enforcement. As far as traffic rules and regulations are concerned, this is part of the road-users' daily education that is going on in our schools, not just part of the syllabus. It is

Column: 1144

part of the duty of teachers to see that children in the schools learn about these rules and why they should be observed for the safety not only of themselves but also of others in the community.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, obviously there is room for much improvement.

     Dr Ong Leong Boon (Kim Seng): Sir, when I raised the point on the Highway Code I was hoping that the Minister would perhaps consider giving a copy of the Highway Code to the driver every time he renews his driving licence. I mentioned my confusion regarding my knowledge of the Highway Code because I had the experience of driving behind the Hon. Minister himself, and it was quite an exercise in updating my knowledge of the new Highway Code.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, I do not know what the Member for Kim Seng is implying by making that point.

    With regard to the Highway Code, as I said, this was part of the theme of the campaign last year. In fact, before the main campaign was launched in June, there had been mini campaigns where each month a rule in the Highway Code was devoted. In fact, if the Member for Kim Seng were to drive with alertness and care, he would see that some of these slogans, like "Do Not Road Hog", are still displayed at the rear of SBS buses. Well, he can learn a lot by being more alert.

     Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Sir, last Friday the Hon. Minister mentioned about kayu. Actually, I said that a police officer called the motorist kayu. How can the Hon. Minister use the word kayu? Is it a parliamentary word? The Minister should not use it.

    Sir, unlike the Minister, I am not going to call anyone kayu. The reason why I mentioned about the police officer calling the motorist kayu is to draw the attention of this House to an abuse in the issue of summonses.

     The Chairman: Mr Govindaswamy, what do you mean by "kayu"? I was not here last Friday. Do you mean "kepala kayu'?

Column: 1145



     Mr P. Govindaswamy: You are a "kayu" It means a piece of wood. The police officer called the motorist "kayu" and I only mentioned what the police officer said. But the Minister should not use the word "kayu".

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Fong Sip Chee): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Anson said "you". I hope he was not referring to the Chair!

     The Chairman: Mr Govindaswamy, surely you are not referring to the Chair as "kayu"?

     Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, I was referring to the police officer who called the motorist kayu. It seems that the Minister has not answered my question correctly. Even if, as is alleged by the Minister which I gather is not true, the motorist had abused the plainclothes police officer and called him kayu, how did this spark off? If there was no spark there would not be any fire.

    It appears that the Minister is defending his department which I think is rightly his duty. No doubt every Minister has to defend his department. But then my question was aimed at stopping the abuse in the issue of summonses. This is very important.

    If I am not mistaken, what I learnt from the Minister's reply on Friday is that it is in order for any plainclothes officer from any department to issue a summons without properly identifying himself, even though the public request to see the warrant card, because of doubt. If that is the case, we would not be surprised to see that many impersonators will take advantage of the situation. Could the Minister enlighten us on this point?

    The Minister had also stated that the motorist had shown disrespect for the court. This is a matter of opinion. Everybody must respect the court. It seems that the Minister is unaware that many people, not only this motorist, do not take the trouble to go to court, not because they have no respect for the court but for many other reasons, like whether or not it is economically wise to go to the court, or for reasons best known to the person concerned. Therefore, it is not fair for

Column: 1146

the Minister to give me an answer which is not to the point.

    Sir, today the Minister asked why this man did not go and make a police report. Yes, that man went and reported to the police. The police did not receive the report because he went against the police. How can they receive the report? [Interruption].

    Sir, I am not joking about this matter. The Minister has got to give instructions to the Traffic Police to take the necessary action wherever possible. If he is a plainclothes police officer, he must show his warrant card. If he does not show his warrant card, nobody will respect him and nobody will give a correct answer. That is why I raised this point in the House.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, the Member for Anson, and he is a good Friend of mine, quoted the saying that if there is no spark there would be no fire. I entirely agree with him. The only thing with regard to this debate on kayu or wood is that the spark came from him. It was he who introduced that expression in this august chamber. It was he who complained that the police officer in plainclothes, after having booked the motorist called him a kayu.

     Mr P. Govindaswamy: Yes.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, I do not know if, in fact, that incident happened. What I said in clarification was that this motorist, after having been booked, went to the Traffic Police Department to complain that he did not commit the offence. But in spite of this - that he said he did not commit the offence - he paid the fine and said that it was a waste of time to go to court because the police officer explained to him that if he was not satisfied he could go to the court to say that he did not commit the offence. Instead he paid the fine and giving the excuse that it was a waste of time to go to court. That is why I said in reply, not showing any disrespect to the Member or to the motorist that if a person who is innocent, after going to the Police Department and is told that if he is innocent he can go to the court and challenge it, still pays a fine, which means

Column: 1147

that he is admitting his guilt, then he must be a real kayu. I hope the Member understands that.

    About disrespect to the court, if a person were to say that it is a waste of time to go to court and challenge it to prove his innocence, I think he is being disrespectful to the court, I hope he is not implying that the court is also kayu.

     Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, I agree with the Hon. Minister's explanation. The motorist explained to the Traffic Police saying, "I am innocent of the charge." The police officer said "If you are innocent, then go to court." The motorist did not want to go to court and so he paid the fine. If he goes to court, it is a waste of time. There are so many things involved here. The Minister must consider. The Minister is right when he said "If you are innocent, you go to court." No doubt he is right. But how many people are willing to go to court? Has the Minister checked with the Traffic Police to find out the number of people who went to court to prove their innocence? Nobody will go to court. It is a waste of time, waste of money. So they pay the fine. Anyway, I have brought up this matter so that the Hon. Minister can instruct the Traffic Police that next time a police officer in plainclothes stops anybody, he has to show his warrant card to identify himself.

    Sir, I do not want to talk too much. I am only asking the Minister to give instruction that in future any plainclothes officer who arrests or issues a summons to anybody should show his warrant card.
